titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ethan Allen Hitchcock Collection on Indian Removal
Hitchcock (Ethan Allen) Collection on Indian Removal
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 04:44

did.unittitle: Ethan Allen Hitchcock collection on Indian removal

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection documents several episodes in the history of Indian removal in the southeastern United States and Missouri, focusing on the activities of Generals Ethan Allen Hitchcock and Thomas Sidney Jesup in the 1830s and early 1840s. Material includes autograph letters, signed, and manuscript reports, diaries, and maps.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English. Includes letters in Choctaw and Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from various sources, 1963-1994, as noted in the description of each acquisition.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The custodial history of material described here is not entirely known. Notes that accompany some acquisitions indicate that Ethan Allen Hitchcock collected documentation relating to the Creek War of 1836, to the Second Seminole War, and to Indian removal campaigns generally. In order to facilitate research on Hitchcock's activities relating to Indian removal, the Beinecke Library has described several acquisitions of topically related material as a collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Ethan Allen Hitchcock Collection on Indian Removal is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ethan Allen Hitchcock Collection on Indian Removal. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2012. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to the date of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call numbers: WA MSS S-947, WA MSS S-1068, Uncat WA MSS 55, Uncat WA MSS 146, Uncat WA MSS 147, Uncat WA MSS 174

bioghist.head: Ethan Allen Hitchcock (1798-1870)
bioghist.p: Ethan Allen Hitchcock was born in Vergennes, Vermont in 1798. He graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1817 and was a career Army officer. He served in the Second Seminole War, the Mexican-American War, and the Civil War. A philosopher and scholar, he published several monographs, including Remarks Upon Alchemy and the Alchemists (1857), Swedenborg: A Hermetic Philosopher (1858), and Christ the Spirit (1860). His memoirs are collected in A Traveler in Indian Territory: The Journal of Ethan Allen Hitchcock (Cedar Rapids, Ia., The Torch Press,1930).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents several episodes in the history of Indian removal in the Southeastern United States, focusing on the activities of Generals Ethan Allen Hitchcock and Thomas Sidney Jesup in the 1830s and early 1840s. Material includes autograph letters, signed, and manuscript reports, diaries, and maps.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five groupings: 1963 Acquisition, 1964 Acquisition, 1986 Acquisition, 1992 Acquisitions, 1994 Acquisition.

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Office of Indian Affairs

did.unittitle: 1963 Acquisition

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by Frederick W. Beinecke for the Western Americana Collection, from Edward Eberstadt & Sons, Catalogue 161 (item 56), 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The acquisition consists of Ethan Allen Hitchcock correspondence, chiefly letters to Commissioner of Indian Affairs Carey A. Harris. The correspondence relates to the removal of Indians from Missouri Territory, treaties, conflicts between the military and the Office of Indian Affairs, appropriations by Congress, delay in remittances and inaccurate accounts, padded muster rolls, transportation of goods, and the possible transfer of Hitchcock.

Other correspondents include Alfred Bronson, J. Hartley Crawford, Charles Findlay, Lucy Hitchcock, Stephen Watts Kearny, William D. McKissack, F. Pfister, J. T. Sprague, Joshua Pilcher, M.M. Vineyard, and Major Wade.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call number: WA MSS S-947

did.unittitle: Ethan Allen Hitchcock correspondence
Ethan Allen Hitchcock correspondence
Ethan Allen Hitchcock correspondence
1964 Acquisition

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Edward Eberstadt on the Beinecke No. 1 Fund, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The acquisition consists of letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock to John Canfield Spencer in 1842, when Hitchcock was stationed at Fort Wayne, Indiana. The correspondence relates to the ill treatment of Indians by soldiers, and justification of the Cherokee claims of insufficient rations and funds. In addition Hitchcock advises the abandonment of Fort Wayne as it has outlived its usefulness.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call number: WA MSS S-1068

did.unittitle: Ethan Allen Hitchcock Letters to John Canfield Spencer
1986 Acquisition

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Goodspeed's Book Shop, Inc., on the Library Associates Fund, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The acquisition consists of a diary by Thomas Sidney Jesup, and letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock to Major Samuel Cooper and to Secretary of War John C. Spencer.
General Thomas Sidney Jesup's "Diary of Events Etc. in the Creek Campaign" relates Jesup's experience in the campaign to remove the Creeks from Alabama in 1836.

Letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock in Fort King and Tampa Bay, Florida to Major Samuel Cooper in Washington, D.C., relate Hitchcock's experience in the Second Seminole War. An accompanying note indicates that the letters were returned from Cooper to Hitchcock in 1841.
Letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock to Secretary of War John C. Spencer relate to the return of documents that Hitchcock had copied, and to the Second Seminole War.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call number: Uncat WA MSS 55

did.unittitle: Diary of Thomas Sidney Jesup
Letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock to Major Samuel Cooper
Letters from Ethan Allen Hitchcock to John C. Spencer (retained copies)
1992 Acquisitions

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Goodspeed's Book Shop, Inc. on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into folders based on geographic region or tribe, as received by the Beinecke Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The acquisitions consist of correspondence, maps, reports, and notes relating to General Thomas Sidney Jesup, to General Ethan Allen Hitchcock, and to removal campaigns against Indians of the Southeast, including Seminole, Choctaw, Creek, and Cherokee.

Correspondence includes three letters in the Choctaw language from the 1830s and 1840s (two written by Jonathan Cogswell), and one letter from a group of removed Creek Indians to the president of the United States, describing their journey to Indian Territory and requesting that the remainder of their tribe join them.

Other letters are written by military personnel and Indian agents in Alabama, Florida, and elsewhere in the Southeast, and document removal activities and military relations with Southeastern Indian people (including the Creek War of 1836 led by Generals Thomas Sidney Jesup and Winfield Scott).
Also included are rolls of children sent to boarding schools and of Indian people who were removed to Oklahoma, chiefly to Fort Gibson.
The notebooks of General Ethan Allen Hitchcock record his research on the Creek Indians in 1842, in Canadian, Oklahoma.
Manuscript maps document military activity and forts in Florida, and the Cherokee Reservation in Arkansas.
Many letters are originals; others are manuscript copies.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call numbers: Uncat WA MSS 146, Uncat WA MSS 147

1994 Acquisition

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co. on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The acquisition consists of notes and correspondence relating to the Second Seminole War and to Indian removal generally. Includes an account by Thomas Sidney Jesup, autograph manuscript, relating the capture of Seminole chief Osceola.
